articles.headline: ‘Together, We Can Become a Force’: Haitians Seek Change After Assassination
articles.snippet: Civic leaders hope that in the midst of the turmoil, the country can find a way to reimagine itself for a better future.
articles.abstract: Civic leaders hope that in the midst of the turmoil, the country can find a way to reimagine itself for a better future.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Teachers and religious leaders, lawyers and farmers, they are veterans of crisis who thought they had seen it all in recent years, looking on in outrage as the democracy they were fighting for was whittled away, gutted under the watch of President Jovenel Moïse.

articles.headline: How Germany Hopes to Get the Edge in Driverless Technology
articles.snippet: A new law allows autonomous vehicles in everyday use and provides legal consistency lacking in the United States.
articles.abstract: A new law allows autonomous vehicles in everyday use and provides legal consistency lacking in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In Hamburg, a fleet of electric Volkswagen vans owned by a ride-hailing service roams the streets picking up and dropping off passengers. The vehicles steer themselves, but technicians working from a remote control center keep an eye on their progress with the help of video monitors. If anything goes wrong, they can take control of the vehicle and steer it out of trouble.

articles.headline: Vocal Anti-Vaccine Chiropractors Split the Profession
articles.snippet: The conflict among chiropractors has become more consequential as the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads and the rate of new vaccinations slows.
articles.abstract: The conflict among chiropractors has become more consequential as the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads and the rate of new vaccinations slows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anyone who listened to the Idaho chiropractor Steven Baker’s podcast in May would have heard a cornucopia of misinformation about the coronavirus and the vaccines protecting hundreds of millions of people against it.

articles.headline: Inside Facebook’s Data Wars
articles.snippet: Executives at the social network have clashed over CrowdTangle, a Facebook-owned data tool that revealed users’ high engagement levels with right-wing media sources.
articles.abstract: Executives at the social network have clashed over CrowdTangle, a Facebook-owned data tool that revealed users’ high engagement levels with right-wing media sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in April, the people behind CrowdTangle, a data analytics tool owned by Facebook, learned that transparency had limits.

articles.headline: Selling Fruit Where the Taliban Stalk the Streets
articles.snippet: For weeks, the northern city of Kunduz has suffered daily street battles. Times journalists were there to document a cat-and-mouse war for control.
articles.abstract: For weeks, the northern city of Kunduz has suffered daily street battles. Times journalists were there to document a cat-and-mouse war for control.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — The Afghan way of war in 2021 comes down to this: a watermelon vendor on a sweltering city street, a government Humvee at the front line just 30 feet away, and Taliban fighters lurking unseen on the other side of the road.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: Europe Unveils Plan to Shift From Fossil Fuels, Setting Up Potential Trade Spats
articles.snippet: The proposal would impose tariffs on some imports from countries with looser environmental rules. It would also mean the end of sales in the European Union of new gas- and diesel-powered cars in just 14 years.
articles.abstract: The proposal would impose tariffs on some imports from countries with looser environmental rules. It would also mean the end of sales in the European Union of new gas- and diesel-powered cars in just 14 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In what may be a seminal moment in the global effort to fight climate change, Europe on Wednesday challenged the rest of the world by laying out an ambitious blueprint to pivot away from fossil fuels over the next nine years, a plan that also has the potential to set off global trade disputes.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Fed Chair Powell Sees Months of High Inflation, but Then Moderation
articles.snippet: Price gains are up “notably,” Jerome Powell told House lawmakers. That’s because of several temporary factors.
articles.abstract: Price gains are up “notably,” Jerome Powell told House lawmakers. That’s because of several temporary factors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, told House lawmakers on Wednesday that inflation had increased “notably” and was poised to remain higher in coming months before moderating — but he gave no indication that the recent jump in prices will spur central bankers to rush to change policy.

articles.headline: How Europe’s Ambitious New Climate Agenda Will Affect Businesses
articles.snippet: The far-reaching plan to reduce the trade bloc’s carbon footprint includes tougher mandates for automakers, steel makers, airlines, energy producers and other industries.
articles.abstract: The far-reaching plan to reduce the trade bloc’s carbon footprint includes tougher mandates for automakers, steel makers, airlines, energy producers and other industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Cars with internal combustion engines will disappear from European showrooms by 2035. Steel producers and cement makers will pay for every ton of carbon dioxide their factories emit. Cargo ships may not be able to dock in ports like Rotterdam or Hamburg unless they run on cleaner fuels. Commercial airliners will be required to fill up with synthetic fuel produced with green energy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Stanley Reed and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Why You Should Care About Your Right to Repair Gadgets
articles.snippet: New legislation could simplify tech maintenance and make buying a new smartphone or computer the last resort.
articles.abstract: New legislation could simplify tech maintenance and make buying a new smartphone or computer the last resort.
articles.lead_paragraph: When your car has problems, your instinct is probably to take it to a mechanic. But when something goes wrong with your smartphone — say a shattered screen or a depleted battery — you may wonder: “Is it time to buy a new one?”
